716641f.title: Manhattan: Beaver Street - Hanover Street
716641f.text:
82-78 Beaver Street, adjoining and east of the S. E. corner
of Hanover Street. At the left is an excavation that extends
to Pearl Street, tho the latter is not shown.
July 6, 1903
Wurts Brothers
716641f.folder: Beaver Street & Hanover Street, Manhattan, NY

716638f-a.title: Manhattan: Beaver Street - Hanover Street
716638f-a.text:
Beaver Street, north side, east from and across
Hanover Street, showing the low Brown Bros. and Co.
buildings under demolition. Adjoining same is the 25
story Munson S. S. Line Building, a triangular structure
at the apex formed by Beaver Street converging with
Wall Street. At the left margin is a portion of the
Canadian Bank of Commerce, a building subsequently de-
molished for the 59 story City Bank Farmers Trust Co.
Building.
Views 2 and 3 are down Exchange Place, a before and
after demolition view of the aforementioned Brown Bros.
Building. To the right here is the Canadian Bank of
Commerce again, on the left being the National City
Bank.
Views: 1,2 March 27, 1928
View 3: June 10, 1928
P. L. Sperr
716638f-a.folder: Beaver Street & Hanover Street, Manhattan, NY

720329f-b.title: Manhattan: Hanover Street - Beaver Street
720329f-b.text:
Hanover Street, east side, north from Beaver Street to Exchange
Place, showing workmen erecting scaffolding for the demolition of the
Brown Bros. & Co. Building, which occupies that block. On the left,
appears the National City Bank Building, at the N.W. corner of Exchange
Place.
March 27, 1928.
T. L. Sperr.
A part of the same, showing the Brown Bros. Co. Building in an ad-
vanced stage of demolition. This site is now (1937) ocoupied by the
35-story Wall and Hanover Building.
Juae 10, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
720329f-b.folder: Hanover Street & Beaver Street, Manhattan, NY

720329f-a.title: Manhattan: Hanover Street - Beaver Street
720329f-a.text:
Hanover Street, east side, north from Beaver Street to Exchange
Place, showing workmen erecting scaffolding for the demolition of the
Brown Bros. & Co. Building, which occupies that block. On the left,
appears the National City Bank Building, at the N.W. corner of Exchange
Place.
March 27, 1928.
T. L. Sperr.
A part of the same, showing the Brown Bros. Co. Building in an ad-
vanced stage of demolition. This site is now (1937) ocoupied by the
35-story Wall and Hanover Building.
Juae 10, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
720329f-a.folder: Hanover Street & Beaver Street, Manhattan, NY

720328f-a.title: Manhattan: Hanover Street - Exchange Place
720328f-a.text:
Hanover Street, west side, between Exchange Place (richt), and Beaver
Street (left), showing the 8-story building of the Canadian Bank of
Comerce. It was demolished in 1929, and on its site now stands the 59-
story City Bank and Farmer's Trust Company Building. The clearance in the
foreground, is at the N.E. corner of Beaver Street, and was created by the
demolition of the Brown Bros. and Co. Building. On its site now (1937),
stands the 35-story Wall and Hanover Building.
June 30, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
720328f-a.folder: Hanover Street & Exchange Place, Manhattan, NY

716639f-b.title: Manhattan: Beaver Street - Hanover Street
716639f-b.text:
(1)
74-70 Beaver Street, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of
Hanover Street, as seen from the N.E. corner of Hanover Street.
The view also shows Hanover Street, west side, from and including
Beaver to Pearl Streets.
September 22, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same showing more of No. 70,which is the Coffee Exchange Building.
September 22, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

720327f-a.title: Manhattan: Hanover Street - Beaver Street
720327f-a.text:
Panover Street, north from Seaver to Wall Streets, showing (right), a
portion of the Wall and Hanover Buildings on the N.E. corner. Hanover Street
at Exchange Place makes a bend in an easterly direction, thereby hiding from
view the east side of the street, and exposing the west side, from Exchange
Place to Wall Strcets, showing the National City Bank Suilding, oooupying that
block. A foot hridge can be seen connecting the latter building, with the
35-story Wall and nanover Buildings.
June 13, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
720327f-a.folder: Hanover Street & Beaver Street, Manhattan, NY

720330f-a.title: Manhattan: Hanover Street - Wall Street
720330f-a.folder: Hanover Street & Wall Street, Manhattan, NY

716637f-a.title: Manhattan: Beaver Street - Hanover Street
716637f-a.text:
Beaver Street, east from William across Hanover to Pearl Streets,
showing the lower portions of the skyscrapers that fill this, the
financial district; that on the left is the City Bank, Farmers Trust
Company, and on the right, the New York Cotton Exchange.
November 7, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
716637f-a.folder: Beaver Street & Hanover Street, Manhattan, NY

716636f-a.text:

71 Beaver Street at the N.W. corner of Hanover Street, as seen
across demolitionefrom South William Street.
902  August 27, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a roof on South William Street, showing the
continuation of Beaver Street, north side, to Wall Street.
August 27, 1929.

716640f-a.title: Manhattan: Beaver Street - Hanover Street
716640f-a.text:
7G-78 and 80 Beaver Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Hanover
Street, as seen across the site of Lrown Bros. 5 Co. Building. Also s hon
(background), is the Hanover Square station of the Second and Third Ave.
Elevated Line.on Pearl Street.
June 10, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
716640f-a.folder: Beaver Street & Hanover Street, Manhattan, NY

720326f-a.title: Manhattan: Hanover Street - Wall Street
720326f-a.text:
Hanover Street, south from all to Beaver Streets, showing the building
of Brown Bros. 3 Co. (left foreground). Hanover Street at Exchange Place,
makes a bend in an easterly direction, thereby hiding from view, the east side
of the street, and exposing the west side.
March 27, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

1507567-a.title: Hanover Street #7 - Beaver Street - Pearl Street
1507567-a.folder: Hanover Street #7 - Beaver Street - Pearl Street, Manhattan, NY

723935f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - Hanover Street
723935f-a.text:
Wall.Street, south side, west from and
including Hanover Street, showing the Custom House.
This structure was originally the Merchants Exchange.
About the turn of the century it became the present
National City Bank.
This photo is a duplicate of a print in-
cluded in this collection.
1886
Gift Thru New York Historical Society
723935f-a.folder: Wall Street & Hanover Street, Manhattan, NY
